text:
Those are your words, not ours. 

We can't write stories based on what "seems" and what doesn't. We've written what we know—and so far, we know she had a difficult past, police ignored the man who had threatened her before, and she was beaten up over the weekend.
author: AnupKaphle

text: No, responsible journalism is trying to paint as full of a picture as we can. And I'd argue that the responsibility of a reader is to read the entire piece *before* drawing conclusions—not from a couple of paragraphs that the story begins with.
author: AnupKaphle

text: The reporter wrote 1,000 words on the tragedy, trying to humanize the victim. You're parsing and drawing conclusions just from the lede that clearly says she used to drink, which led to her quitting her job and get back into sex work, which she knew was a dangerous profession.
author: AnupKaphle

author: AnupKaphle

text:
One of the park officials accused in the death of Shikharam admits using waterboarding on poaching suspects. 

When asked about it, he said: “It was not torture, it was interrogation.”

The official has a memoir, based on which a movie is being released soon.
author: AnupKaphle

text: Locals in villages in Chitwan—including fishermen and women who collect firewood—told the Post they are regularly harassed by park authorities, wronged by the government, and ignored by conservation agencies.
author: AnupKaphle

text: Over the years, there have been several reported incidents of forest rangers and Nepal Army soldiers—1,000 soldiers are deployed in Chitwan park alone—engaging in abuse and torture of members of indigenous groups who live around the protected areas.
author: AnupKaphle

text:
Despite WWF’s claim that it does not tolerate any brutality by its partners, a year-long investigation by @BuzzFeedNews, which Post partnered with, shows the group has continued to fund, equip, train and support violent forces.

Read the BuzzFeed story:
author: AnupKaphle

text:
Hira, Shikharam’s wife, said park officials asked her to settle the case. “Let bygones be bygones,” she said the officials told her.

Mangaram, Shikharam's brother, told the Post that behind closed doors, various interest groups kept pressuring his family into dropping the case.
author: AnupKaphle

text: WWF Nepal welcomed the government’s decision, and bragged about their efforts "lobbying with major political parties and the government for their release.” WWF Nepal later hired one of the suspects and rewarded a second suspect.
author: AnupKaphle

text:
Shikharam Chaudhary was suspected of aiding poachers and arrested from his home in Chitwan in 2006. Nine days later, he died.

The government withdrew the case against park officials who were charged with homicide.

Detainees told the Post they were tortured in this hut.
author: AnupKaphle

text:

A short thread on our investigation into the killing of a Tharu man, and how WWF Nepal continues to ignore rights violations inside national parks.

text:
NEW: Kathmandu Post responds to Traveller Assist's statement on Medium accusing our story of falsehoods

And we have receipts.
author: AnupKaphle

text:
Read @arpanshr and @sangamprasai's report on how an international medical assistance company has been threatening government officials, helicopter companies and rescue agencies in Nepal http://bit.ly/2DvH4Dg 

We're aware of TA's response and will release a statement soon.
author: AnupKaphle

text: “Authorities seem to be trying to insert some provisions in such a way that they can be used to control the media." http://bit.ly/2DtWBDf  — @tikapradhan's report on the media laws drafted by the provincial governments
author: AnupKaphle

text:
While government investigation into fraudulent rescue scams continues, the Central Investigation Bureau told the Post that it was also investigating the Traveller Assist official who has been sending emails to ministry and private companies.

Full story
author: AnupKaphle

text: The company does not have any offices in Nepal, according to the Department of Industry, contrary to the claims on Traveller Assist's website that it has an operations centre in Kathmandu. http://bit.ly/2DvH4Dg
author: AnupKaphle

text:
The Post also discovered that Traveller Assist used a fake article with a Kathmandu Post reporter's byline to tout its services and promote its image in the country. http://bit.ly/2DvH4Dg 

Here's our reporter looking super amused when he saw his fake byline —
author: AnupKaphle

text: Traveller Assist also simultaneously wrote to helicopter companies and rescue agencies, claiming that it was working with the Nepal government. But government officials denied that they are working with Traveller Assist, and have never heard of—or from—the company.
author: AnupKaphle

text: After sending two ultimatums to the tourism ministry, Traveller Assist wrote to government officials asking them to appoint them as the point agency for rescue and insurance coordination in the country. http://bit.ly/2DvH4Dg
author: AnupKaphle

text:
EXCLUSIVE: A Post investigation shows that Traveller Assist, an international medical assistance company, used lies to threaten the government, private rescue agencies and hospitals in Nepal

Extraordinary reporting by @arpanshr + @sangamprasai http://bit.ly/2DvH4Dg

text:
“My father was born in this country and lived his whole life here. I was born here and have lived here my whole life. My siblings are all Nepali citizens. This is the only country I know. Where do I go now?” Pramod says.

Read, share, comment
author: AnupKaphle

text: Pramod's father also never had citizenship—not because he didn't qualify but because he couldn’t afford to pay the bribe government officials demanded. He died a stateless man. http://bit.ly/2MSKwfc
author: AnupKaphle

text: Pramod is the only person in the village to have gone to college, but when he graduated three years ago, he couldn’t get employed because he didn’t have citizenship. http://bit.ly/2MSKwfc
author: AnupKaphle

text: Most children in the village work on farms with their parents. Kes Rani says there's no point in sending her children to school because they won't get a job without citizenship. So when Manoj, her eldest son, stopped attending school, she was okay with it. http://bit.ly/2MSKwfc
author: AnupKaphle

text:
They don’t know any other home than Nepal. But they’re still stateless.

An incredibly important story by @TseringNgodupL1 on how arcane laws and govt bureaucracy have left families without citizenship and pushed them further into poverty.  http://bit.ly/2MSKwfc

text: What I'll do next: I’ll become the new editor-in-chief of The @KathmanduPost and lead the digital transformation of Kantipur Media Group, including its TV and radio platforms. I started my journalism career in Kathmandu, and I’m totally elated to head home to begin a new chapter.
author: AnupKaphle

text: After 15 years in the US, I’m moving back home to Nepal. It’s been one hell of an adventure, and if I had to re-do all of it again, I would still start my American life in Tennessee and end in New York. Washington, you'd still be my home for the longest time here.

text: We also haven’t talked about alcohol. When you’re in Kathmandu, you’ll want to embrace the local homebrew. Here’s a beautiful love letter to the fiery Nepali Raksi, by Prawin Adhikari.

text: We haven’t talked about food. There’s plenty to eat, but may we recommend this little pocket of buffalo tripe and bone marrow—straight from the gods. @RukshanaNewa on Sapoo Mhicha, the disappearing dish.

text: Kathmandu is a city of many cultures, shaped by the indigenous Newars as much as by the hippies. @Amish973 explains what Nepal’s capital means to its people, through 11 songs. Our soundtrack to Kathmandu.
author: AnupKaphle

text: That said, getting out of Kathmandu is a must. We recommend spending a day in Patan, just 20 minutes away. So much to see, and so many things to eat.
author: AnupKaphle

But the refugee issue is not something you want to bring up if you plan to travel there. Here is what you need to know before you go to Bhutan.

text: Most people don’t know that Bhutan expelled thousands of citizens, classifying them as illegal aliens, in the late 80s and early 90s. @TPMishra wrote this compelling essay on what it was like to flee home http://bit.ly/2M7JYRb  #WorldRefugeeDay
author: AnupKaphle

text: Today is a big day, and a special day, for us at @RoadsKingdoms. We have a book out today that we published with our friend and partner Anthony Bourdain—a deep dive into Italy that tells stories about its food and the people who make them.  More on http://bit.ly/pasta-pane-vino
author: AnupKaphle

text:
This Italian town is known for its war against McDonald's. When the fast-food chain arrived here in the early 2000s, locals fought with focaccia, sausage, and bread.

Today, the town is also known for its divine cheese—and these brothers who make them. http://bit.ly/burrata-brothers …
author: AnupKaphle

text:
These brothers roam the earth like bounty hunters, possessed by one simple idea: where there’s milk, there’s mozzarella.

Read our latest story in the Dispatched by Bourdain series, an excerpt from our new book on Italy by @mdgoulding.

The journey of a Chechen woman who followed her husband to Syria and Iraq to live with ISIS, before she finally managed to flee
author: AnupKaphle

text: Iman's long journey to the ISIS-held territory began in the small Kazakh town of Aktau. Within a month, she was in Raqqa before finally moving to Tal Afar, where she'd spend the next two years. http://bit.ly/run-iman
author: AnupKaphle

text: In 2014, Iman’s husband tricked her into traveling to Dagestan and then told her they were moving to Raqqa. When she refused, he threatened to take their son and go anyway. Iman gave in. http://bit.ly/run-iman
author: AnupKaphle

text: This is Iman Muzaeva, who was among the several dozen women rescued from the ISIS-held territory last year by the Russian government. http://bit.ly/run-iman

Bangladeshi officials say drug gangs are taking advantage of the Rohingya crisis. These days authorities regularly conduct drug raids inside the camps. Here, undercover police officers drag Rohingya men during one of the raids.

author: AnupKaphle

text: Drug dealers say they use Rohingya women for two reasons—if they're single and desperate for work, they are easier to manipulate; and they're less likely to be checked by police. They also ask mothers to bring their babies, so they look less suspicious.
